abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Municipal Development
            Project for Cote d'Ivoire was unsatisfactory. The
            project did not achieve its major objectives, institutional
            development was partially achieved, sustainability is
            unlikely, and the performance of the Bank was marginally
            satisfactory while the Borrower's was unsatisfactory.
            Several lessons can be learned from this project. First,
            urban development projects, in particular, municipal
            development projects, whether works or policy oriented, must
            be conceived and implemented in a decentralized context.
            Second, a municipal development project based on a
            decentralization process and aimed at supporting that
            process cannot be managed in a centralized way without the
            active participation of municipalities. Also, in such a
            project, the government's commitment to
            decentralization cannot be taken for granted, since the
            government's priorities may change. Third, it is
            essential that loan documentation includes performance
            indicator covenants and a plan for a mid-term review to
            facilitate the monitoring and evaluation of the project and
            canceling of the loan if the project is not properly
            implemented. Finally, the Bank should pay more attention to
            the continuity of the staff working on a project and ensure
            that the assigned staff has the right kind of expertise.
